awd_titl_txt: Diastereodivergent Catalysis with Modularly Designed Organocatalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
The Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division supports the project by Professor John Zhao. Professor Zhao is a faculty member in the Department of Chemistry at the University of Texas at San Antonio (UTSA).  He is developing a new method for the selective synthesis of multiple stereoisomers of organic molecules.  Stereoisomers, which differ only subtly in their structures, may have totally different biological and/or pharmacological properties. The goal of this research project is to exploit the unique properties of modularly designed organocatalysts (MDOs) to achieve the easy synthesis of multiple diastereomers of complex organic molecules from the same starting materials, which is presently a very challenging task in chemistry. The research greatly facilitates the exploration of new chemical space and drug discovery. This project offers research opportunities for students, including students from underrepresented minorities, who are preparing for careers in the chemical sciences. UTSA is one of the most diverse institutions of higher education in the United States. Professor Zhao's group provides a high level of education and training for students through a variety of outreach programs that are already in place at UTSA.

Catalytic asymmetric syntheses of multiple diastereomers of various important polysubstituted carbocyclic and heterocyclic compounds are under investigation.  The researchers use the same starting materials and different modularly designed organocatalysts to selectively generate different stereoisomers of the targets. Specifically, Professor Zhao is pursuing the development of novel MDO catalysts that are self-assembled from readily available precatalysts and the utilization of the MDOs in the catalytic tandem reactions for the diastereodivergent synthesis of polysubstituted carbocyclic and heterocyclic compounds. The method is being investigated for the diastereodivergent syntheses of bioactive natural products of medicinal relevance. The research provides new catalysts that not only achieve the divergent synthesis of different stereoisomers of important molecules, but also improves the stereoselectivity in the synthesis.   Stereoselective synthesis is a current challenge in asymmetric catalysis. The research results are being incorporated into an organic laboratory aimed at undergraduates to help stimulate their interest and attract these students to the chemical sciences.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: University of Texas at San Antonio

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Texas at San Antonio

por.por_cntn:
Under the support of the NSF award CHE-1664278, we investigated the application of modularly designed organocatalysts (MDOs), which are self-assembled from α-amino acids and cinchona alkaloid derived (thio)ureas and squaramides, in the diastereodivergent synthesis of important carbo- and heterocyclic compounds. We successfully applied MDOs in the highly enantioselective and diastereodivergent synthesis of several important carbo- and heterocyclic structures, such as 4-oxocyclohexanecarbaldehydes, bridged tetrahydroisoquinolines, and hexahydro-6H-benzo[c]chromen-6-ones. We also achieved the highly enantioselective synthesis of biologically active molecules, such as chromane derivatives and spiro[4H-pyran-3,3’-oxindole] derivatives. In the course of this research, we also discovered the enzyme-like allosteric regulations of the MDO systems. Our results clearly demonstrated the advantages of using MDOs in asymmetric diastereodivergent synthesis of carbo- and heterocyclic products that are important for organic synthesis and medicinal chemistry. The method we developed should greatly facilitate the exploration of new chemical space and drug discovery. Besides the 13 papers we have published, we two additional submitted manuscripts and one more manuscript under preparation. Our research results were also presented in 16 local, regional, national, and international conferences via posters and oral presentations, with two of those have won a poster award from the conferences.

I utilized the mechanisms available at UTSA and built connections with local high schools to introduce the research opportunities in the Chemistry Department and our lab to undergraduate, graduate, and high school students. During the past five years, our lab has trained 22 undergraduate students, 2 graduate students, 2 high school students, 9 post-doctoral fellows, and 1 visiting scholar. Many of them are women and/or from the underrepresented groups. Several undergraduate students and one of the high school students have achieved publications after their training in my lab. As one of the organizers, I helped organize the Third International Symposium on Carbene and Nitrene Chemistry, which was attended by more than 150 chemists around the world (with 37 plenary or invited lectures). I also built a connection with a local robotic team composed of middle school students and gave two lectures to these students.

 


Last Modified: 08/29/2022
Modified by: John Zhao
